unnormalised: Interventional cardiology has revolutionized the treatment of cardiovascular diseases in India. This subspecialty of cardiology focuses on catheter-based techniques to diagnose and treat a wide range of heart conditions. Minimally invasive procedures have largely supplanted traditional open-heart surgeries, offering patients reduced recovery times and fewer complications. This article provides an overview of the recent advancements and current practices in interventional cardiology, with a specific focus on their application within the Indian healthcare system.

unnormalised: One of the most common procedures performed by interventional cardiologists is percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), also known as angioplasty. PCI involves inserting a catheter into a blood vessel, typically in the arm or groin, and guiding it to the blocked or narrowed coronary artery. A balloon is then inflated to open the artery, and a stent, a small metal mesh tube, is deployed to keep the artery open. Drug-eluting stents (DES) are now the standard of care, releasing medication to prevent restenosis, the re-narrowing of the artery. Studies have shown that DES reduce the risk of repeat procedures by up to 70% compared to bare-metal stents. In India, Dr. Devi Shetty's Narayana Hrudayalaya hospitals are renowned for their high volume of PCI procedures and commitment to affordable cardiac care.
normalised: One of the most common procedures performed by interventional cardiologists is percutaneous coronary intervention (P-C-I), also known as angioplasty. P-C-I involves inserting a catheter into a blood vessel, typically in the arm or groin, and guiding it to the blocked or narrowed coronary artery. A balloon is then inflated to open the artery, and a stent, a small metal mesh tube, is deployed to keep the artery open. Drug-eluting stents (D-E-S) are now the standard of care, releasing medication to prevent restenosis, the re-narrowing of the artery. Studies have shown that D-E-S reduce the risk of repeat procedures by up to seventy percent compared to bare-metal stents. In India, Doctor Devi Shetty's Narayana Hrudayalaya hospitals are renowned for their high volume of P-C-I procedures and commitment to affordable cardiac care.

unnormalised: Beyond PCI, interventional cardiology encompasses a range of other procedures. Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) is a minimally invasive alternative to open-heart surgery for patients with severe aortic stenosis, a narrowing of the aortic valve. TAVR involves inserting a replacement valve through a catheter and deploying it within the diseased valve. TAVR is particularly beneficial for elderly or high-risk patients who are not suitable candidates for traditional surgery. According to a report in "The Hindu" dated 12/05/2023, TAVR procedures are becoming increasingly common in major Indian cities like Mumbai and Delhi.

unnormalised: Another area of advancement is in the treatment of structural heart disease. Procedures such as atrial septal defect (ASD) and patent foramen ovale (PFO) closure are now routinely performed using catheter-based techniques. These procedures involve inserting a device through a catheter to close the abnormal opening in the heart. Similarly, percutaneous mitral valve repair, using devices like the MitraClip, offers a less invasive option for patients with mitral regurgitation, a condition in which the mitral valve leaks. AIIMS, New Delhi has been a pioneer in adopting these techniques in India.

A-I-I-M-S, New Delhi has been a pioneer in adopting these techniques in India.

unnormalised: Intravascular imaging techniques, such as intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) and optical coherence tomography (OCT), play a crucial role in guiding interventional procedures. IVUS uses ultrasound to visualize the inside of the coronary arteries, providing detailed information about plaque composition and vessel dimensions. OCT uses light to create high-resolution images of the arterial wall. These imaging modalities help cardiologists to optimize stent placement and ensure complete lesion coverage. Data suggests that the use of IVUS can reduce stent thrombosis by approximately 40%.

unnormalised: Furthermore, the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) is transforming interventional cardiology. AI-powered algorithms can analyze angiograms and other imaging data to identify areas of stenosis and predict the risk of future cardiac events. ML models can also be used to personalize treatment strategies based on individual patient characteristics. A recent study published in the "Indian Heart Journal" on 20/07/2024 showcased how AI improved the accuracy of lesion detection by 25%.

A recent study published in the "Indian Heart Journal" on twentieth July two thousand and twenty four showcased how A-I improved the accuracy of lesion detection by twenty five percent.

unnormalised: Despite the remarkable advancements, challenges remain. Access to advanced interventional cardiology services is still limited in rural areas of India. The cost of procedures and devices can also be a barrier for many patients. However, government initiatives and philanthropic organizations are working to improve access and affordability. For instance, the "Ayushman Bharat" scheme provides financial assistance for cardiac procedures to eligible individuals. As of Q3 2023, over 10,000 patients have benefitted from this scheme for cardiac treatments in the state of Tamil Nadu alone.

unnormalised: In conclusion, interventional cardiology has made significant strides in the diagnosis and treatment of cardiovascular diseases in India. Continued innovation and investment in research and infrastructure will be crucial to further improve patient outcomes and expand access to these life-saving procedures. With ongoing advancements in technology and increasing expertise among cardiologists like Dr. Rajesh Sharma, interventional cardiology will undoubtedly play an increasingly important role in shaping the future of cardiac care in India.
